answers.q: is ammonium chloride soluble in water
answers.a: Yes—ammonium chloride is readily soluble in water, forming a clear, mildly acidic solution.
No; it's a salt (NH4Cl) of a strong acid and a weak base, but its water solutions are mildly acidic (typically around pH 5–6).

answers.q: is ammonium chloride the same as ammonia
answers.a: No; ammonia is NH3 (a gas/aqueous base), while ammonium chloride is a crystalline salt composed of the ammonium ion (NH4+) and chloride.

answers.q: what is ammonium chloride used for
answers.a: As a food additive (E510) it serves as an acidity regulator, dough conditioner/yeast nutrient, and provides the characteristic taste in salty licorice; it can also support fermentation in some processes.
No; it is not used or authorized as an antifungal preservative in foods—its permitted uses are for acidity regulation, processing, and flavoring rather than mold control.
